Ruthenium-based catalysts exhibit excellent catalyst activity in the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction and tend to be a good substitute for mercury-based catalysts due to their cheaper price among the precious metal catalysts. In this work, spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out to investigate the properties of the ruthenium single-atom catalysts supported on six different substrates (four pyridine nitrogen-doped carbon, four or three pyrrole nitrogen-doped carbon, C2N, CN and g-C3N4), and the reaction mechanisms of acetylene hydrochlorination catalyzed by them at 453 K. According to the results of calculations, it could be found that the reaction had the lowest free energy barrier of 16.83 kcal/mol on the Ru@4 × N6 (pyridine nitrogen-doped carbon), while it had the highest free energy barrier of 49.06 kcal/mol on the Ru@g-C3N4. This work will provide a theoretical support for the design of ruthenium single-atom catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acetylene hydrochlorination Mechanism Density functional theory Ru single-atom catalyst 1 Introduction Vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) is an important chemical material, usually used for the production of polyvinyl chloride (PVC), which is widely used in the field of industry, construction, agriculture as a kind of common engineering plastic. Since China has more coal than oil resource, VCM is generally produced through the route of acetylene hydrochlorination reaction [1,2]. However, the catalyst used in industrial production is mostly mercury-based catalyst, which is harmful to human health and environment [3,4]. Therefore, it is significant to develop mercury-free catalysts which are efficient and environmentally friendly. Recently, single-atom catalysts (SACs) which contain metal atoms dispersed on a substrate at the atomic level have received widespread attention. SACs have shown outstanding performance in several reactions such as nitrogen reduction reaction [5–7], hydrogen evolution reaction [8], CO2 reduction reaction [9–11], etc. Various metals such as the noble metals Au [12–14], Pd [11,15,16], Pt [17,18], Ru [19–22] and non-noble metals Fe [23–25], Co [26], Cu [27–29] and Ni [30–32] have been applied as catalytic sites in single-atom catalysts for catalytic reactions and perform well. Ruthenium, an element of the platinum group metals, has cheaper price among the precious metal. In recent years, there have been more and more studies on ruthenium-based catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination, and their excellent activity, stability, and price advantage have been affirmed by numerous researches [33–36]. Meanwhile, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were executed by Zhu et al. [37] to explore the energy barriers for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction catalyzed by HgCl2, AuCl3 and RuCl3 as 16.3 kcal/mol, 11.9 kcal/mol and 9.1 kcal/mol, respectively. After comparison, it could be observed that the reaction catalyzed by RuCl3 had the lowest energy barrier, indicating that the Ru-based catalyst was more suitable for the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. Kaiser et al. [38] synthesized a series of Ru-based catalysts and found that RuOxCly as the active component could achieve the same activity level as Au-based catalysts. Although RuCl3 species as single-atom active sites were reported as inferior catalysts compared to RuOxCly nanoparticles in this work, it is possible to enhance the activity of single-atom catalysts by regulating the coordination environment of Ru through different substrates. Generally, Ru single-atom catalyst has already been investigated in the HER [39,40] and NRR [41,42], however, they have rarely been explored for catalytic hydrochlorination of acetylene [43]. All above studies on single-atom catalysts can prove that, in some cases, SACs have better performance on stability, catalytic activity and selectivity due to their special structure. As the size of the metal bulk decreases, the atomic utilization rate will reach the theoretical maximum value when single atom is loaded, and sometimes exhibits better catalytic performance than NP-based catalysts, however, there is no doubt that the cohesive energy of the metal surface rises sharply in this process [44]. Isolated single metal atoms tend to agglomerate easily, so it is very important to find a suitable substrate to anchor single metal atom stably [45]. Therefore, metal oxides [46,47], carbon nanotubes [48,49], MOF [50,51] and nitrogen doped graphene [52–55] have been investigated to act as substrates. Among them, carbon materials are excellent substrates for dispersing metal atoms because of their large specific surface area, excellent conductivity and superior mechanical strength, while manufacturing defects and N doping can anchor single atoms more stably and prevent their agglomeration [56]. In this study, single-atom Ru was anchored by N atoms on the different nitrogen doped carbon-based supports to form Ru-N structure. DFT was used to investigate the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction mechanism over different catalysts, and the results revealed the reactants adsorption, free energy barrier and reaction mechanism for this reaction. All of the above will provide new insights to design novel Ru single-atom catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. 2 Computational methods The spin-polarized DFT calculations were carried out by the DMol3 code in Materials Studio software [57,58]. The unconstrained geometry optimizations were calculated using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [59] exchange-correlation functional in the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with a double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis set for all the atoms. 20 Å vacuum slab was added along the z-direction to ensure no potential interactions between each layer, and the k-point was set as a 3 × 3 × 1 mesh with the orbital cutoff of 4.7 Å [60,61]. Grimme method for DFT-D correction [62] was taken into account and all electron relativistic was selected as the core treatment to improve the accuracy of the results. Other parameters were automatically set, which were optimized during the calculation process. The convergence tolerance of energy, maximum force and maximum displacement were 0.00005 Hartree, 0.002 Hartree per Å and 0.005 Å, respectively. In addition, a smearing of 0.005 Hartree was set to accelerate SCF convergence. The adsorption energy (E ads) between the reactants/products and the catalyst could be used to show the interaction between them. E ads was defined as: E ads = E adsorption state − E free molecule − E catalyst where E adsorption state is the total energy of catalyst with adsorbed reactants/products, E free molecule is the energy of the free reactants/products and E catalyst is the energy of the clean catalyst. Complete linear synchronous transit and quadratic synchronous transit (LST/QST) protocol in DMol3 code was used to search transition state [63], and vibrational frequency analysis was applied to confirm the stationary point. The transition state should have only one imaginary eigenvalue whose vibrational mode corresponds to the reaction coordinate. TS confirmation further verifies that current transition state connects to the reactant and product directly. Considering the influence of real reaction conditions of 453 K and 1 atm, the highest Gibbs free energy barrier (ΔG 453) of the entire reaction pathway was chosen as the activation energy. Δ G 453 = G 453 T S − G 453 s t a t e where G 453 TS is the Gibbs free energy of TS under 453 K, G 453 state is the Gibbs free energy of co-ads or IM configuration under 453 K. What's more, Mulliken charge, density of states (DOS) and electron density difference (EDD) patterns were analyzed to better understand the reaction mechanism. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and electronic properties of the six SACs In this study, six Ru SACs with different substrates (4 × N6, 4 × N5, 3 × N5, C2N, CN, g-C3N4) were selected to investigate the influence on the catalytic activity for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. The binding energy of metal atom loaded on different substrates were all negative, which meant Ru atom could disperse stably at the atomic level instead of agglomerating [64] (Table S1, ESI†). Among them, 4 × N6, 4 × N5 and 3 × N5 substrates exhibited better capture ability. The stable structures of the six catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 (a), where all the substrates were two-dimensional layered materials. In the Ru@4 × N6 and Ru@3 × N5, Ru tended to be anchored in the center of the cavity by forming Ru-N bonds with the distance of 1.986 and 1.965 Å. The distance of Ru out of the plane layer was 0.697 and 0.911 Å. In the Ru@4 × N5, Ru was also supported in the center of the four-fold cavity with the four Ru-N bonds distances of 2.112 Å. However, Ru was not out of the plane layer probably due to the adequate space of four-fold cavity. In the Ru@C2N and Ru@CN, these two kinds of substrates had similar binding behaviors to metal atom, on which Ru was loaded in the corner of the six-fold cavity rather than the center by two Ru-N bonds with the lengths range of 2.002–2.022 Å. Interestingly, it was found that Ru bound to two pyridine N which not connected to the same C by comparing all the possible binding sites of Ru in the Ru@g-C3N4. The electrostatic potential on different catalysts is shown in Fig. 1 (b). The darker red region represented the more negative charges accumulated, while the darker blue region represented the more positive charges accumulated. According to the patterns of Ru@4 × N6, Ru@4 × N5, the negative charge was enriched where the N atoms were, while on Ru@3 × N5, the positive charge gathered around Ru atom, on the other three catalysts, the positive charge gathered around Ru atom, and the negative charge gathered around the N atoms opposite to Ru site. Therefore, the electrophilic reaction tends to occur on the N site enriched with negative charges, while the nucleophilic reaction tends to occur on the Ru site enriched with positive charges. Combining with the electrostatic potential of reactants (Fig. S1, ESI†), the sites where the reactants interacted with catalyst can be predicted. To further clarify the properties of these catalysts, a series of calculations were carried out. The Mulliken charges of Ru atoms in Ru@4 × N6, Ru@4 × N5, Ru@3 × N5, Ru@C2N, Ru@CN and Ru@ g-C3N4 were 0.591 e, 0.558 e, 0.677, 0.611 e, 0.638 e and 0.531 e (Table S3, ESI†), respectively. The positive Mulliken charges indicated that the Ru atoms donated electrons to the substrates, which were consistent with the EDD pattern of each catalyst. As shown in Fig. 1 (c), the blue region surrounding the Ru atom represented the area where the electrons decreased, while the red region surrounding the N atom represented the area where the electrons increased. The results obtained from EDD patterns were in accordance with those from Mulliken charge analysis, which also confirmed the electrons transfer from Ru atom to the N atom of the substrates. In addition, the intersection of the red and blue regions was nearly in the middle of the two atoms, which indicated that a covalent Ru-N bond was formed. In brief, strong metal-support interaction can not only promote the metal stable distribution, but also tune the electronic structure of catalyst. 3.2 Adsorption of reactants and product on different SACs Catalysts with different structures and electronic structures show different adsorption abilities for reactants and product. The stable adsorption configurations and adsorption energies of the six SACs are shown in Fig. 2 and Table 1 . Since the configuration of Ru@4 × N6 was almost the same as that of Ru@4 × N5, the adsorption configurations of reactants and product on them were also similar. HCl was adsorbed nearly vertically on the catalyst surface through the interaction of H and Ru, with the distances of 2.003–2.087 Å. In addition, the H-Cl bond lengths of the adsorbed HCl were 1.359–1.383 Å, while free HCl was only 1.289 Å. These results indicated that HCl was obviously activated by the active site. In contrast, HCl was adsorbed on Ru@3 × N5 through the interaction of Ru and Cl and the interaction of C and H, where the activated H-Cl bond length was 1.319 Å. However, when HCl adsorbed on the other three SACs (Ru@C2N, Ru@CN and Ru@g-C3N4), the Cl of HCl formed the coordination bonds with Ru atoms of catalysts, with the bond lengths of 2.288–2.395 Å. Meanwhile, the H of HCl was captured by the N atom on the opposite side of the six-fold cavity, with the distances of 1.027–1.047 Å. The H-Cl bonds were stretched to 2.133–3.351 Å owing to the different adsorption sites on catalysts for the two atoms of HCl. These results could be considered that H-Cl bond had been broken, which meant that HCl dissociated and adsorbed on the catalysts. Through calculation, the adsorption energies of HCl on the Ru@4 × N6, Ru@4 × N5, Ru@3 × N5, Ru@C2N, Ru@CN and Ru@g-C3N4 were -10.27 kcal/mol, -8.70 kcal/mol, -15.57 kcal/mol, -47.75 kcal/mol, -38.51 kcal/mol and -24.16 kcal/mol, respectively. Obviously, the adsorption energy of HCl increased as the distance between H and Cl increased, indicating the higher activation degree of HCl, and the stronger interaction with catalysts. Different from the HCl adsorption, the adsorption configurations of C2H2 on the different catalysts were similar. The C of C2H2 bound to Ru, forming two Ru-C bonds, with the lengths of 2.042–2.153 Å when C2H2 adsorbed on the catalysts. The structures of C2H2 also changed after adsorption. Both H atoms of C2H2 shifted away from the catalyst, with the CC bonds were stretched from 1.259 to 1.293 Å, and the C2H2 molecule no longer maintained a linear configuration, which all indicated the activation of C2H2. The adsorption energies of C2H2 on the Ru@4 × N6, Ru@4 × N5, Ru@3 × N5, Ru@C2N, Ru@CN and Ru@g-C3N4 were -44.24 kcal/mol, -35.17 kcal/mol, -38.87 kcal/mol, -30.09 kcal/mol, -38.82 kcal/mol, -33.07 kcal/mol, respectively, which meant strong chemical interactions between C2H2 and all catalysts. The difference in adsorption of C2H2 among different catalysts could be explained by d-band center theory, as for Ru@4 × N6, Ru@3 × N5 and Ru@CN with stronger adsorption of C2H2, the d-band center was closer to the Fermi energy level compared with others [65,66] (Table S4, ESI†). Additionally, d-band center could also explain why Ru@4 × N6 had better activation ability for reactants compared to Au and Pt SACs identified the same site (Fig. S2, Tables S5–S7, ESI†). It is generally believed that the activation of acetylene has an important effect on promoting the hydrochlorination reaction, therefore, ab initio molecular dynamic (AIMD) was carried out to confirm the stability of the configuration with the strongest adsorption of acetylene [67] (Figs. S3 and S4, ESI†). Furthermore, the product VCM was adsorbed due to the interaction between Cl and Ru, with the adsorption energies were -16.80 kcal/mol, -15.33 kcal/mol, -9.59 kcal/mol, -18.51 kcal/mol, -15.68 kcal/mol, -15.71 kcal/mol, respectively. The low adsorption energy indicated that the product was physically adsorbed on the catalyst surface so it was easy to desorb from the catalyst, avoiding the deactivation of the catalyst caused by covering the active sites. The Mulliken charges of reactants were analyzed (Tables S8 and S9, ESI†), it was found that the H atom in HCl lost electrons, while Cl atom got electrons during the adsorption of HCl by all the catalysts. Subsequently, the H-Cl bond activated in different degree with HCl no longer maintained electrical neutrality. HCl obtained 0.112 e, 0.086 e, and 0.073 e over Ru@4 × N6, Ru@4 × N5 and Ru@g-C3N4, respectively, whereas over the other three catalysts Ru@3 × N5, Ru@C2N and Ru@CN, HCl lost 0.145 e, 0.004 e and 0.011 e. These results indicated that catalysts with different substrates played different roles in HCl activation process, acting as electron donors or electron acceptors. Combining with the comparison of adsorption energies, it was obvious that there might be a stronger interaction between HCl and catalyst with larger degree of HCl activation when electrons were transferred from HCl to catalysts, which was in accordance with the ideas of adding alkaline sites [33]. As for the adsorption behaviors of C2H2, the other five catalysts all acted as electron acceptors, except for Ru@g-C3N4. The Mulliken charges of activated C2H2 were 0.100 e, 0.229 e, 0.025 e, 0.156 e, 0.055 e and -0.062 e, respectively. 3.3 Co-adsorption configuration on different SACs Based on the above results of separate adsorption of each reactant, the most stable co-adsorption configurations on these catalysts were investigated (Fig. 3 ). Obviously, the adsorption energies of HCl were much smaller than those of C2H2 on Ru@4 × N6, Ru@4 × N5 and Ru@3 × N5, thus the adsorption of HCl was carried out based on the adsorption of C2H2. It could be observed from the most stable adsorption configuration that on Ru@3 × N5, the Ru single-atom site which adsorbed C2H2 could still interact with Cl atom of HCl. However, it was found that the Ru active sites which had adsorbed C2H2 could not adsorb HCl simultaneously, due to the saturated coordination states of the Ru atoms on Ru@4 × N6 and Ru@4 × N5. Therefore, HCl was adsorbed by the interaction of H with adjacent pyridine N. C2H2 and HCl were adsorbed on the catalyst surface together, and formed a “T-structure”, which was similar to the adsorption structure without catalyst. In the most stable co-adsorption configuration, C2H2 was adsorbed and activated over Ru site, with the CC bond lengths of 1.281 and 1.265 Å. The C-Ru bond lengths were 2.092∼2.112 Å, and the molecule lost its linear configuration. Apparently, HCl was adsorbed and activated by adjacent pyridine N with the H-N distance of 2.835 and 2.677 Å, and the H-Cl bond lengths were stretched to 1.306 and 1.301 Å. There was no doubt that C2H2 was preferentially adsorbed by the catalyst over Ru@CN and Ru@g-C3N4 due to the larger adsorption energies for C2H2 than HCl, however, there were some differences from the above three catalysts. In the co-adsorption configurations, Ru active sites which had already adsorbed C2H2 still donated to the adsorption of HCl and the H-Cl bond lengths were 3.927 and 2.221 Å, respectively, which revealed that HCl was still dissociated and adsorbed. The Cl of HCl interacted with Ru and formed Ru-Cl bonds with the lengths of 2.341 and 2.402 Å, while the H of HCl adsorbed by the pyridine N on the opposite side of the Ru atom and the N-H bonds were 1.030 and 1.045 Å. As for Ru@C2N, HCl was dissociated and adsorbed firstly, where the coordination bond of Ru-Cl was 2.371 Å and the length of N-H bond was 1.027 Å and then C2H2 was captured and activated by Ru site by forming two Ru-C bonds. The EDD patterns of the co-adsorption configurations are shown in the bottom panel of Fig. 3, blue and yellow regions represented electron accumulation between Ru and C atom and electron depletion of Ru atom, respectively. To further understand the bond formation in the co-adsorption configurations over different catalysts, the electronic partial density of states (PDOS) was carried out. Herein, only Ru@4 × N5 and Ru@C2N are selected as representatives for analysis, more details are exhibited in supporting information. Fig. 4 (a) shows the PDOS patterns before and after reactants co-adsorbed on Ru@4 × N5. Through comparison, it was obvious that the electronic states of s and d orbitals of Ru atom were significantly reduced after the co-adsorption, which was same as the charge analysis (Table S10, ESI†), in which the Mulliken charge of Ru in the co-adsorption configuration was reduced compared to the clean catalyst. Furthermore, the bonding orbital and antibonding orbital between the d orbital of Ru in the catalyst and the p orbital of C in the C2H2 formed obviously near the Fermi level, indicating the formation of the Ru-C bond. However, the s orbital of H1 in HCl was not hybridized with the s or d orbital of Ru, which meant that HCl was not adsorbed or activated on Ru sites. This result was consistent with the observed co-adsorption configuration. Fig. 4(b) shows the PDOS patterns before and after reactants co-adsorbed on Ru@C2N. After adsorption, the electronic states of s and d orbitals of Ru atom also decreased dramatically, and the d orbital of Ru in the catalyst and the p orbital of C in the C2H2 were hybridized near the fermi level. The hybridization of orbitals illustrated the interaction between C2H2 and the Ru active site. In addition, the s orbital of H1 in HCl and the p orbital of N which anchored metal atoms on the catalyst were partially hybridized, while the p orbital of Cl in HCl and the d orbital of Ru were also hybridized. These results proved that HCl was dissociated in which Cl atom was adsorbed by Ru site, and H was captured by N atom. In summary, for these six catalysts, Ru atom and N atom acted as dual active sites to adsorb and activate the reactants, the reaction occurred between the adsorbed HCl and adsorbed C2H2 subsequently, therefore, the reaction should follow the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism. 3.4 Catalytic mechanisms of different SACs The study of the entire catalytic pathway of acetylene hydrochlorination started with the isolated catalyst and the gas phase reactants whose total energy was regarded as the zero point of free energy. The reaction was initiated by the co-adsorption and activation of the two reactants, after passing several transition states and intermediates, the product VCM was generated and then finally desorbed from the catalyst surface. 3.4.1 Catalytic mechanism over Ru@4 × N6, Ru@4 × N5 and Ru@3 × N5 Herein, Ru@4 × N6 was selected to discuss the catalytic mechanism in detail (Fig. 5 ), since the reaction pathway over Ru@4 × N5 and Ru@3 × N5 were similar. After C2H2 and HCl were adsorbed on the catalyst surface, the H1 atom of HCl moved to C1 of *C2H2, and the Cl atom of HCl moved in the opposite direction. Meanwhile, the distance between C1-H1 was shortened from 2.284 Å in co-adsorption to 1.098 Å in transition state 1 (TS1), and the H1-Cl bond length increased to 4.162 Å during this period. Subsequently, the first intermediate IM1 was formed, H1 atom was added to C1 of *C2H2 to form *C2H3, while Cl was captured by the H3 atom on the other side of *C2H3 with the H3-Cl distance of 2.302 Å. The hydrogenation process was endothermic and would overcome an energy barrier of 12.89 kcal/mol. Because of the unsaturated coordination of Ru after *C2H3 was formed, the Cl which was captured by H3 was finally adsorbed by Ru site, with the Ru-Cl bond length of 2.432 Å of IM2. The energy decreased from IM1 to IM2, however, the energy barrier for this step was 7.06 kcal/mol. Then, the adsorbed Cl atom was added to the *C2H3, during which the Cl gradually attacked the C2 of *C2H3, and generated the ads-VCM vertical to the catalyst surface. Finally, the VCM desorbed from the catalyst surface, exposing the catalytic sites, and entered the next reaction cycle. According to the calculation result, the free energy barrier of the Cl addition process was 16.83 kcal/mol, which made this step the rate-limiting step in the catalytic pathway. To discover the orbital interaction, PDOS of the reaction mechanism was carried out (Fig. 6 ). The s orbital of H1 atom was hybridized with p orbital of C1 atom in IM1 indicated the formation of H1-C1 bond. Bonding states around -2.8 eV between p orbital of C2 and Cl atom were observed gradually from IM1 to ads-VCM. Compared with the above conclusion, the reaction mechanism of acetylene hydrochlorination on Ru@4 × N5 still had some differences (Figs. S6 and S7, ESI†). First of all, the elementary step in which Cl adsorbed by Ru with the free energy barrier of 22.24 kcal/mol was the rate-limiting step in the catalytic pathway. Secondly, the final product ads-VCM tended to be parallelly adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst and then desorbed from the surface easily. Different from the mechanism on Ru@4 × N5, due to the unsaturated coordination of Ru on Ru@3 × N5, Cl atom was directly adsorbed by Ru site after H addition process (Figs. S8 and S9, ESI†). What's more, Cl addition reaction with the energy barrier of 43.88 kcal/mol was the rate-limiting step. 3.4.2 Catalytic mechanism over Ru@C2N and Ru@CN The reaction pathway on Ru@CN was similar with that on Ru@C2N, so, the one with better catalytic performance was chosen as an example to analyze the detailed mechanisms. The reaction pathway over Ru@CN is shown in Fig. 7 . Different with the above two catalysts, the H1 and Cl of dissociatively adsorbed HCl were adsorbed on the opposite side of *C2H2. Afterwards, the H1 adsorbed on N site desorbed to attack the C1 atom of *C2H2 at first, and the H1-N bond was elongated to 1.355 Å, while the distance of H1-C1 reduced to 1.398 Å, which was the structure of TS1. After passing TS1, the distance between H1 and C1 continued to decrease until the H1-C1 bond was formed with a bond length of 1.097 Å, indicating the first intermediate *C2H3 was formed. According to the calculation, the first elementary reaction should overcome the energy barrier of 23.11 kcal/mol, during which H-adding reaction occurred. Moreover, as the result of the lower coordination of the Ru site, the intermediate *C2H3 and Cl atoms were both adsorbed on Ru active site, forming a Ru-Cl bond length of 2.355 Å and two Ru-C bonds with the bond lengths of 1.883 and 2.222 Å, respectively. The Cl adsorbed on the Ru site could directly add to the *C2H3 to form ads-VCM, so the step of the Cl atom migration was omitted compared to the above two catalysts. Before product VCM was generated, there was still another free energy barrier of 24.32 kcal/mol for Cl-adding reaction, where Cl kept approaching C2 atoms of *C2H3 with the distance of Cl-C2 decreasing from 3.164 to 2.188 Å until TS2 was formed. At the same time, the Ru-C1 bond was broken, and the *C2H3 specie bound to Ru site with only one Ru-C2 bond with the length of 2.268 Å. After passing TS2, the distance of Cl-C2 decreased until the product VCM was formed. During this process, the Ru-C2 bond was elongated and eventually broken and VCM was adsorbed on the Ru site parallelly through the Ru-Cl bond of 2.492 Å. At last, the active sites were released by desorption of ads-VCM, and provided adsorption sites for other reactants to promote subsequent reaction. In conclusion, the Cl addition process became the rate-limiting step over the entire reaction pathway. The initial reaction step was that the H1 of HCl attacked and added to the C1 of *C2H2 to form the intermediate *C2H3 over the Ru@C2N, followed by Cl atom which was adsorbed on Ru site approaching the C2 atom of *C2H3 continuously to generate ads-VCM. What's more, the rate-limiting step was also the Cl-adding step with an energy barrier of 27.29 kcal/mol, which was higher than 17.74 kcal/mol required by H-adding step (Figs. S11 and S12, ESI†). 3.4.3 Catalytic mechanism over Ru@g-C3N4 The minimum energy path of chemical reaction with the optimized structures in the illustration is shown in Fig. 8 . The reactants were co-adsorbed on the catalyst surface, where the Cl and H1 of dissociatively adsorbed HCl were located on the same side of *C2H2. As the first step of the reaction, the H1 atom adsorbed on the N site starts to desorb and then constantly approach the C1 atom in *C2H2. During this period, the energy barrier of 24.27 kcal/mol needed to be overcome to form TS1 with only one imaginary frequency which vibrational mode connected to the reactant and product. The H1 continued to move closer to C1, binding to C1 with the bond length of 1.095 Å eventually, resulting in the breakage of Ru-C1 bond, which represented the formation of intermediate *C2H3. The second step was the addition of Cl, where Cl attacked the C2 atom of *C2H3 to form ads-VCM and the energy barrier should be overcome to generate TS2 was 49.06 kcal/mol, which made this step the rate-limiting step of the entire reaction pathway. The product VCM was adsorbed parallelly to the surface of the catalyst through the interaction of Cl and Ru atom. It could be regarded as a physical interaction between the adsorbed product and the catalyst, resulting from the distance of 3.224 Å, which meant the product was easily desorbed from the catalyst surface to release the active site. In order to make a systematic understanding of the above six catalysts, the reaction paths on six catalysts are compared (Fig. 9 ), and the Gibbs free energy barriers of the rate-limiting step for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction on each catalyst are listed in Table 2 . The order of the free energy barrier for each catalyst was Ru@4 × N6 < Ru@4 × N5 < Ru@CN < Ru@C2N < Ru@3 × N5 < Ru@g-C3N4, in other words, the catalytic activity was in the order of Ru@4 × N6 > Ru@4 × N5 > Ru@CN > Ru@C2N > Ru@3 × N5 > Ru@g-C3N4. Compared with the result obtained from previous work, the reaction energy barrier was 38.05 kcal/mol on pure graphene [68], which proves that Ru@3 × N5 and Ru@g-C3N4 have little catalytic activity for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction. In contrast, Ru@4 × N6, Ru@4 × N5, Ru@C2N and Ru@CN all significantly reduce the reaction energy barrier and exhibit excellent activity. The high energy barrier of Ru@g-C3N4 could be explained by the structure change of the catalyst during the reaction process. The other catalysts basically maintained a flat two-dimensional structure in the whole reaction, however, there was an obvious deformation for Ru@g-C3N4 at the beginning of adsorbing the reactants until the product desorption. Whether it is the deformation of the adsorbed reactants or the catalyst, it always indicates the strong interaction between them. As far as we know, the catalyst needs to provide a moderate interaction to the reactants or intermediates, otherwise, it will be not conducive to the subsequent reaction. What's more, previous work also confirmed that low coordinated Ru site would make it difficult to provide Cl to *C2H3 to produce VCM [69], which is in accordance with the phenomenon in this calculation result. 3.5 Impact of chlorination of Ru sites Previous experiment observed that Ru sites were easily chlorinated during the reaction [38,55]. Herein, based on the reaction energy barrier, 4N-coordinated Ru@4 × N6, 3N-coordinated Ru@3 × N5 and 2N-coordinated Ru@CN were selected as representatives to study the effect of chlorination of active sites on catalyst itself and on adsorption capacity of reactants. Compared with isolated Ru atom, the binding energies of Ru species with Cl coordination were reduced, indicating that the bonding strength of substrate to chlorine-containing Ru species was weaker than isolated Ru single atom (Table 3 ). As the coordination number of Ru increased, the adsorption and degree of activation of the reactants was reduced, which might have an adverse effect on the activity of single-atom catalysts (Fig. S14, Table S18, ESI†). In order to further explore the effect of chlorination on activity, the best-performing @4 × N6 was selected as substate to load RuCl specie, and it was found that the reaction energy barrier significantly increased to 39.76 kcal/mol, indicating that chlorination is unfavorable for the activity of Ru single-atom sites (Fig. 10 ). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the catalytic mechanisms of acetylene hydrochlorination reaction on Ru single-atom catalysts with six different nitrogen-doped carbon-based substrates were investigated via DFT calculation in this study. The result showed that the catalytic performance was in the order of Ru@4 × N6 > Ru@4 × N5 > Ru@CN > Ru@C2N > Ru@3 × N5 > Ru@g-C3N4. The first four catalysts can effectively reduce the energy barrier required by the whole reaction pathway but unfortunately Ru@3 × N5 and Ru@g-C3N4 exhibit poor catalytic performance. In particular, Ru@4 × N6 is the most promising catalyst among all the six catalysts due to its lowest energy barrier of 16.83 kcal/mol compared to others. Furthermore, the adsorption energies of the product VCM are below -18.51 kcal/mol for all the six catalysts, which can be described as physical interaction and indicates that the product VCM easily desorb from the catalysts after it is formed. Only in this way can the active sites be exposed to other reactants and continuously produce products which means that these catalysts will have a satisfactory catalyst lifetime. Therefore, this theoretical research will provide a new sight into the design of stable and efficient Ru single-atom catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. coredata.dc:description: Ruthenium-based catalysts exhibit excellent catalyst activity in the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction and tend to be a good substitute for mercury-based catalysts due to their cheaper price among the precious metal catalysts. In this work, spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out to investigate the properties of the ruthenium single-atom catalysts supported on six different substrates (four pyridine nitrogen-doped carbon, four or three pyrrole nitrogen-doped carbon, C2N, CN and g-C3N4), and the reaction mechanisms of acetylene hydrochlorination catalyzed by them at 453 K. According to the results of calculations, it could be found that the reaction had the lowest free energy barrier of 16.83 kcal/mol on the Ru@4 × N6 (pyridine nitrogen-doped carbon), while it had the highest free energy barrier of 49.06 kcal/mol on the Ru@g-C3N4. This work will provide a theoretical support for the design of ruthenium single-atom catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination reaction.
